title: Binance Pulls Out of Deal to Acquire Rival Crypto Exchange FTX
abstract: The rapid collapse of FTX, built by the billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried, suggests that no company in the freewheeling, loosely regulated crypto industry is safe.

multimedia.caption: Sam Bankman-Fried, the head of FTX, was seen as one of the most reliable leaders of the crypto industry.

title: Is This Crypto’s Lehman Moment?
abstract: Here’s how to make sense of the industry-shaking collapse of FTX.

multimedia.caption: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder and chief executive of FTX, had been viewed as a sort of poster boy for the crypto industry.

title: On Twitter, Elon Musk Details His Plans for Twitter’s Business
abstract: Mr. Musk, the social media service’s new owner, has been looking for ways to generate more revenue at the company.

title: Can New Technology Make Home Dialysis a More Realistic Option?
abstract: The Tablo System promises to make dialysis easier and more convenient for patients. But there are significant barriers to the technology.

title: Tech’s Talent Wars Have Come Back to Bite It
abstract: Hiring the best, the brightest and the highest number of employees was a badge of honor at tech companies. Not anymore as layoffs surge.

title: Remaking the River That Remade L.A.
abstract: Over the past century it has been channeled, subdued, blighted. Is it time for the Los Angeles River to serve the city in a new way?

title: L.A. Drops Criminal Charges Against Election Software Executive
abstract: Eugene Yu was accused of illegally sending data about poll workers to China, in a case that became fodder for election deniers.

title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Did Not Perform at Its Best on Election Day
abstract: False narratives about voting in the midterm elections proliferated on the platform, which has shed half its employees since Mr. Musk bought the company last month.

title: How News About Maricopa County’s Ballot-Counting Machines Went Viral
abstract: Claims spread from fringe accounts to the mainstream, with help from prominent influencers on Twitter.

title: Meta Lays Off More Than 11,000 Employees
abstract: The parent of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reduced its work force by 13 percent and extended a hiring freeze through the first quarter of next year.

title: Smartphones Are Like Cars. So Why Don’t We Maintain Them?
abstract: Regularly replacing our phones takes a toll on our wallets and the environment. We should instead take care of them as we do our cars.

title: Patience, Please! Networks Urge Caution on a Chaotic Midterm Night.
abstract: “Wait for more votes,” warned CNN’s John King, as wary anchors tried to avoid any predictions that might go awry.
byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Jeremy W. Peters

multimedia.caption: Bill Hemmer of Fox News. Like other networks, Fox told viewers that final results would take time.

title: Elizabeth Holmes Denied New Trial and Is Set to Be Sentenced
abstract: The founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos faces a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison.

title: Crypto World Is Rocked as World’s Largest Exchange Rescues Rival
abstract: Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, said it had reached a deal to buy FTX, amid fears the industry could enter another meltdown.
byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith

multimedia.caption: Changpeng Zhao, founder and chief executive of Binance. “This afternoon, FTX asked for our help,” Mr. Zhao said on Twitter on Tuesday.

title: Greece to Ban Sale of Spyware After Government Is Accused of Surveillance
abstract: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced the ban after a news report claimed that he had directed the use of spyware against prominent politicians and journalists, which he denied.
byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
des_facet: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece has acknowledged that state intelligence was monitoring an opposition party leader with a wiretap.

title: Apple Could Be Short of iPhones Because of Factory Disruptions in China
abstract: The company said Covid-19 restrictions were slowing production of the company’s new phones ahead of the holiday season.

title: Meta Is Said to Plan Significant Job Cuts This Week
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said last month that many “teams will stay flat or shrink over the next year” as his company faces economic challenges.

multimedia.caption: The job cuts at Meta could be the most significant at the company since it was founded in 2004.
The job cuts at Meta could be the most significant at the company since it was founded in 2004.

title: Twitter Is Said to Delay Changes to Check Mark Badges Until After Midterms
abstract: Users and employees had raised concerns that Elon Musk’s plan to give check marks to those who paid a monthly fee could be misused to sow discord.
byline: By Ryan Mac, Kate Conger and Mike Isaac

multimedia.caption: Charging for the verification check mark program had been one of the changes made by Twitter’s new owner, Elon Musk.
Charging for the verification check mark program had been one of the changes made by Twitter’s new owner, Elon Musk.

title: Russia Reactivates Its Trolls and Bots Ahead of Tuesday’s Midterms
abstract: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.

multimedia.caption: The St. Petersburg building that is said to be the site of the Russian Internet Research Agency. Cybersecurity researchers have tied the agency to a new Russian misinformation effort.

title: How Republicans Fed a Misinformation Loop About the Pelosi Attack
abstract: Within hours of the brutal attack last week on Paul Pelosi, Republican officials and media figures began circulating groundless claims — nearly all of them sinister, and many homophobic — about what had happened.
byline: By Annie Karni, Malika Khurana and Stuart A. Thompson

title: YouTube May Have Misinformation Blind Spots, Researchers Say
abstract: The video platform said it had limited the spread of misinformation ahead of Election Day, but new research showed that false narratives continued to slip through.

multimedia.caption: The nonprofit Media Matters identified a variety of videos on YouTube that contained misinformation.
The nonprofit Media Matters identified a variety of videos on YouTube that contained misinformation.

title: Fed Up With Political Text Messages? Read On.
abstract: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.

title: On Twitter, Who Needs a Check Mark When You Can Have a Rat?
abstract: Elon Musk wants Twitter users to pay to be verified. An artist offers a wry alternative.
